supersat documentation¶

caipeex¶

This package contains code for data processing and analysis of the CAIPEEX field campaign.

example_figsrc¶

Plotting procedure based on https://matplotlib.org/3.1.1/gallery/lines_bars_and_markers/simple_plot.html

Get x values for plotting

caipeex.example_figsrc.main()[source]¶

halo¶

This package contains code for data processing and analysis of the HALO GOAmazon field campaign.

altvst_figsrc¶

altitude vs time, using ‘above sea level’ and ‘pressure’ altitude quantities from ADLR

halo.altvst_figsrc.main()[source]¶

main routine.

checkbins_figsrc¶

check bin size ranges.

comparelwc_set_figsrc¶

Generates set of plots of LWC vs time from ADLR, CAS, and CDP instruments for all flight dates. Also look at effect of 3um diam bin cutoff and adjusting CAS particle correction factor after Weigel 2016.

halo.comparelwc_set_figsrc.main()[source]¶

main routine; calls make_lwc_fig for all flight dates (even if datasets are missing) and all combinations of boolean values for 3um bin cutoff and cas correction factor change.

halo.comparelwc_set_figsrc.make_lwc_figure(adlrdata, datasets, setnames, cutoff_bins, change_cas_corr, date)[source]¶

plot and save lwc comparison (ADLR, CAS, CDP) figure given numerical data and flags to enforce 3um diameter minimum or uniform correction of CAS and CDP data.

halo_data_cleanup¶

First round of HALO data processing: .ames –> .npy, stripping unnecessary metadata from .ames files.

Input location: /data/halo/ames Output location: /data/halo/npy_raw Output format: .npy file containing one dictionary formatted as: {“flight_date”: [‘YYYY’, ‘MM’, ‘DD’], “var_names”: [‘<full var name 1>’, …], “data”: <numpy array with columns labeled by var_names>}

halo.halo_data_cleanup.main()[source]¶

extract flight date, variable names, and data from ames files to numpy files. also convert error codes to np.nan.

halo_data_polish¶

Second round of HALO data processing: extract relevant data for ADLR, CAS, CDP, and NIXE-CAPS sets and convert to mks units.

Input location: /data/halo/npy_raw Output location: /data/halo/npy_proc Output format: .npy file containing one dictionary formatted as: {“dataset”: HALO dataset number XXXX “data”: {“<clean var name 1>”:<numpy array>, …} “units”: {“<clean var name 1>”:<string>, …}}

update 1/20/20: also including LWC data in these files because it takes too long to run each time making figures. Format is dict[‘<data, units>’][‘lwc’][‘<0 or 1><0 or 1>’][<data>], where first boolean corresponds to 3um bin cutoff and second to changing CAS correction factor to match CDP; e.g. ‘01’ means no bin cutoff but yes change CAS correction. There is also dict[‘data’] [‘lwc_t_inds’], i.e. indices of dict[‘data’][‘time’] with which the lwc arrays are aligned (comes from having to match them with ADLR).

halo.halo_data_polish.main()[source]¶

extract time, environment variables from ADLR; time, nconc, and other available quantities from CAS, CDP, AND NIXE-CAPS. also calculate lwc for CAS and CDP.

meanr_scatter_set_figsrc¶

Create and save figure meanr_scatter_set. This is a significant refactoring relative to the previous version of the code, now that I have a better idea what is going on with the data. In particular, condense plotting into a single generic routine to elminate redundancy.

warning: notation with line breaks is inconsistent.

halo.meanr_scatter_set_figsrc.filter_and_rescale(datablock, change_cas_corr, cutoff_bins)[source]¶

Filter out low meanr and/or meanr values; returns (meanr_cas, meanr_cdp)

halo.meanr_scatter_set_figsrc.main()[source]¶

For each date, and also for aggregated data from all dates, make four scatter plots of cloud droplet mean readius values measured by CAS vs CDP: control vs with time offset; control vs correct CAS with xi factor; control vs cutoff bins with particle diameters below 3um; control vs all three of those correction schemes.

halo.meanr_scatter_set_figsrc.make_comparison_scatter(datablock_control, datablock_modified, change_cas_corr, cutoff_bins, mod_label, suffix, date)[source]¶

Make a scatter plot of CAS vs CDP meanr with two data sets, one the original “control” and the other corrected.

nconc_scatter_set_figsrc¶

Create and save figure nconc_scatter_set. This is a significant refactoring relative to the previous version of the code, now that I have a better idea what is going on with the data. In particular, condense plotting into a single generic routine to elminate redundancy.

warning: notation with line breaks is inconsistent.

halo.nconc_scatter_set_figsrc.filter_and_rescale(datablock, change_cas_corr, cutoff_bins)[source]¶

Filter out low nconc and/or meanr values; returns (nconc_cas, nconc_cdp)

halo.nconc_scatter_set_figsrc.main()[source]¶

For each date, and also for aggregated data from all dates, make four scatter plots of cloud droplet number concentration measured by CAS vs CDP: control vs with time offset; control vs correct CAS with xi factor; control vs cutoff bins with particle diameters below 3um; control vs all three of those correction schemes.

halo.nconc_scatter_set_figsrc.make_comparison_scatter(datablock_control, datablock_modified, change_cas_corr, cutoff_bins, mod_label, suffix, date)[source]¶

Make a scatter plot of CAS vs CDP nconc with two data sets, one the original “control” and the other corrected.

optimize_offsets¶

Calculate linear regression parameters for CAS vs CDP in number concentration and mean radius measured values. (Just prints everything out)

halo.optimize_offsets.main()[source]¶

For each date with data from all three instruments, fit CAS vs CDP in number concentration and mean radius to a line and for each time offset, print out R_nconc^2, R_meanr^2, m_nconc, m_meanr

search_NIXECAPS¶

Does NIXE-CAPS actually contain useful data?!?

halo.search_NIXECAPS.main()[source]¶

check if literally any NIXECAPS datasets contain a single timestamp having non-error entries for every particle size bin below 50um

utils¶

various utility methods for halo package.

halo.utils.calc_lwc(setname, setdata, envdata, cutoff_bins, change_cas_corr)[source]¶

calculate liquid water content given particle number concentrations and environmental data.

Returns: (lwc_array, time_inds) -lwc_array = array of lwc values -time_inds = indices of setname array originally passed by user which match indexing of lwc_array (i.e. lwc_array is time-commensurate with setname[time_inds].

update 1/20/20: if envdata is None-valued, return None’s. For cleaner data processing flow.

halo.utils.get_datablock(adlrinds, casinds, cdpinds, adlrdata, casdata, cdpdata)[source]¶

Consolidate data for easier processing Format of output array (order of columns): time, temperature, vertical velocity, cas correction factor, number conc for cas bins (12 cols), number conc for cdp bins (15 cols).

halo.utils.get_ind_bounds(arr, minval, maxval, startind=0)[source]¶

Return: (imin, imax) where arr[imin] >= minval and arr[imax] <= maxval. Assumes arr is sorted smallest to largest (ie time series) Starts sorting at startind in arr, if specified

halo.utils.get_meanr_vs_t(datablock, change_cas_corr, cutoff_bins)[source]¶

Returns (meanr_cas, meanr_cdp)

halo.utils.get_nconc_vs_t(datablock, change_cas_corr, cutoff_bins)[source]¶

Returns (nconc_cas, nconc_cdp)

halo.utils.linregress(x, y=None)[source]¶

~~copy pasta from scipy so I don’t have to import the whole damn module~~ Calculate a regression line This computes a least-squares regression for two sets of measurements. Parameters ———- x, y : array_like

two sets of measurements. Both arrays should have the same length. If only x is given (and y=None), then it must be a two-dimensional array where one dimension has length 2. The two sets of measurements are then found by splitting the array along the length-2 dimension.

slopefloat

slope of the regression line

interceptfloat

intercept of the regression line

r-valuefloat

correlation coefficient

stderrfloat

Standard error of the estimate

halo.utils.match_multiple_arrays(arrays)[source]¶

Return: [inds1, … , indsN] where arr1[inds1] = … = arrN[indsN]. Assumes all arrays are sorted in the same order (ie time series) probably a better way to do this recursively but I never learned that shit xd

halo.utils.match_two_arrays(arr1, arr2)[source]¶

Return: (inds1, inds2) where arr1[inds1] = arr2[inds2]. Assumes arr1 and arr2 are both sorted in the same order (ie time series)
